Message.Title: What do AAPL`s mini pullbacks and up thrusts in parabolic mode look like? And what does a major correction at the end of parabolic mode look like? What to expect here after yesterday`s close of 674ish?
Message.Msg: These would be thrusts and pullbacks that could occur over the course of 1 to 3 trading days. This is predicated on AAPL remaining parabolic or semi-parabolic for at least 8 more trading days. At our current level of roughly 674, these would look like this, from the top down: Extreme thrust up 693 Sharp thrust up 682 Normal thrust up 678 Neutral ---------- Normal pullback 668 Sharp pullback 663 Extreme pullback 656 yes, AAPL could pull back all the way to 656 and still technically be in parabolic mode. Also, each day all of these numbers are rising everyday until we get a sharp pullback. When AAPL corrects from a parabolic-run TOP, it is much more extreme. For example, if Monday at 680.87 was/had indeed been the top, we could expect to see 645 by Friday or Tuesday and 633 over the next 10 days and 622 over the next 2 weeks and 600-595 over the next 10-12 weeks, before another blast off. If Monday was just a swing high in a continuing parabolic or even semi-parabolic run we could easily see between 690 and 710 by September 12. Sideways over the next 2 wks. would be consolidation between 660 and 680. And that`s never bad. Personally I`m expecting a “local” top around 710 followed by a 35 to 65 point correction over 2 months (a wild guess really), before a run up to 830. That assumes i-5 will be a high-5. All a wild guess, actually, however educated.

Topic.Title: Earnings will be a DISASTER. Here's why.

Message.Msg: First off, in one week with an Iphone 5 launch, the numbers can be cushioned by 3-5 million Iphone units, easily. Two, earnings will NOT be stellar, hence the reason the company guided aggressively lower last month. You forget, the company, and now the Street, has brought the bar down after last quarter considerably. But, the questions remains, will people aggressivelly sell the stock? No. Because if the Iphone 5 launch is strong in the first week and the product stellar, ahead of the holiday investors will be forced to buy. Then the company hits you with an Ipad mini during that weakness. Do you really think Apple hasnt thought of this? Do you really think you are the only person that assumes seasonality and a major lull before Iphone 5 will debut? Child please. And for the record, last quarter, the COMPANY guided correctly, easily surpassing their own expectations. They knew what was coming. It was the Street that got it wrong. Hopefully they come more focused and realistic this quarter,

Message.Title: Bill Gross: QE3 is likely
Message.Msg: Gross Says QE3 Likely Even if Bernanke Doesn’t Provide Hint Policy makers will announce more so-called quantitative easing “relatively soon,” Gross, who runs the world’s biggest bond fund, said in an interview on Bloomberg Television’s “Street Smart” with Trish Regan. “They have a dual mandate,” Gross said, referring to the Fed’s directive of price stability and maximum employment. “Unemployment is still above 8 percent and it’s obvious that the Fed isn’t comfortable, nor is the nation or the economy with 8 percent unemployment going forward.” Until the unemployment rate is in the low 7 percent range and inflation has risen above the Fed’s 2 percent target the fed is going to “ease quantitatively,” Gross said from Pimco’s headquarters in Newport Beach, California.

Message.Title: AppleTV w/ 4G.... the next great thing
Message.Msg: just an incredible product for the consumer.... think about how the telecom and cable industry would be turned upside down with this product A. cabletv cord cutting would accelerate.... with hulu, netflixs and itunes the only use for cable would be live sports.... you can get local channels with an antennae..... you can already get baseball on iTunes and AppleTV... football with Sprint... would get to AppleTV B. 4G unlimited access becomes the standard... ... there would be no other way to have 4G TV without unlimited access... this would force all carriers to go unlimited access too.. C. Eventually content providers would have to go the way Apple wants and what consumers want.... and that is to be able to buy individual channels via Apps or via AppleTV... because the market would be shifting to the AppleTV ala carte way.... Apple's little hobby is the "secret" the "game changer" that is going to be the next "monster" product for Apple....... TV gets into the home right now via cable for the most part.... and if you have Fios for your internet you are still stuck with a hard line ..... 4G AppleTV changes that entire dynamic... and is an Apple thing to do....

Message.Title: good old paul ryan..a blatant liar
Message.Msg: Follow The Daily Ticker on Facebook! There was once a time when lying in a political speech--and getting called out on it by the media--was shameful or embarrassing. Not anymore. Now, says Jeff Greenfield, the veteran political analyst and Yahoo! News columnist, the media is held in such low regard by Americans that getting called out for lying merely serves to confirm a widespread belief that the "liberal media" has an axe to grind against conservative politicians. As a result, the whoppers that dominated Republican VP candidate Paul Ryan's convention speech last night will likely not hurt the candidate's standing with Republican voters, says Greenfield. Rather, they'll reinforce the right-wing view that the media is "in the tank" for President Obama. What facts in particular were observers and fact-checkers up in arms about? Well, for starters, there were once again the claims that Obamacare cuts $716 billion of benefits from Medicare and that Paul Ryan wants to preserve Medicare. The truth is that Obamacare reduces payments to hospitals and doctors by $716 billion, not benefits. Also, far from preserving Medicare, after a 10-year grace period, Romney and Ryan want to radically change it. [Related: Romney Adviser: Yes, We're Going To Slash Taxes Without Increasing The Deficit] Then Ryan blamed S&P's downgrade of U.S. debt on Obama, when S&P explained explicitly that its downgrade was the result of Congressional Republicans--Ryan included--threatening to cause the country to default. [Related: No Matter Who Wins the Election, Don't Expect a Deal on the Budget or Deficit: Kotok] Then Ryan accused Obama of lying to voters in his home state by promising to keep a GM plant open for "hundreds of years" after he was elected, only to have it closed in the first year. The truth is that GM closed the plant before Obama took office.

Message.Title: Paul Ryan’s Speech Was Filled With Economic Inaccuracies
Message.Msg: Yahoo!’s Jeff Greenfield: There was once a time when lying in a political speech--and getting called out on it by the media--was shameful or embarrassing. Not anymore. Now, says Jeff Greenfield, the veteran political analyst and Yahoo! News columnist, the media is held in such low regard by Americans that getting called out for lying merely serves to confirm a widespread belief that the "liberal media" has an axe to grind against conservative politicians. As a result, the whoppers that dominated Republican VP candidate Paul Ryan's convention speech last night will likely not hurt the candidate's standing with Republican voters, says Greenfield. Rather, they'll reinforce the right-wing view that the media is "in the tank" for President Obama. What facts in particular were observers and fact-checkers up in arms about? Well, for starters, there were once again the claims that Obamacare cuts $716 billion of benefits from Medicare and that Paul Ryan wants to preserve Medicare. The truth is that Obamacare reduces payments to hospitals and doctors by $716 billion, not benefits. Also, far from preserving Medicare, after a 10-year grace period, Romney and Ryan want to radically change it. Then Ryan blamed S&P's downgrade of U.S. debt on Obama, when S&P explained explicitly that its downgrade was the result of Congressional Republicans--Ryan included--threatening to cause the country to default. Then Ryan accused Obama of lying to voters in his home state by promising to keep a GM plant open for "hundreds of years" after he was elected, only to have it closed in the first year. The truth is that GM closed the plant before Obama took office. And so on. Jeff Greenfield says that none of this will matter to voters, who will just blame the media and its silly "fact-checkers."

Message.Title: HUGE BREAKING LEGAL: GOOGLE TRYING TO SETTLE WITH APPLE!! THIS WOULD BE A HUGE ROYATLTY TO APPLE - TRUST THIS LAWYER
Message.Msg: Page immediately started negotiation with Cook - Cook is THE BEST business CEO This would entail a huge royalty to Apple Page started this immediately after the verdict - the writing clearly being on the wall - Android is on the way to emplosion unless Google brokers this - the Motorola Fiasco purchase for excessive billions blew up in Google's face. Apple separating from Google (Maps, you tube, search I betya) - Google has to hurry up and it is! By Alexei Oreskovic and Poornima Gupta SAN FRANCISCO (Reuters) - Google Inc CEO Larry Page and Apple CEO Tim Cook have been conducting behind-the-scenes conversations about a range of intellectual property matters, including the ongoing mobile patent disputes between the companies, according to people familiar with the matter. The two chief executives had a phone conversation last week, the sources said. Discussions involving lower-level officials of the two companies are also ongoing. Page and Cook are expected to talk again in the coming weeks, though no firm date has been set, the sources said. One source told Reuters that a meeting was scheduled for this Friday, but had been delayed for reasons that were unclear. The two companies are keeping the lines of communication open at a high level against the backdrop of Apple's decisive legal victory in a patent infringement case against Samsung, which uses Google's Android software. A jury awarded Apple $1.05 billion in damages last Friday and set the stage for a possible ban on sales of some Samsung products in a case that has been widely viewed as a "proxy war" between Apple and Google. One possible scenario under consideration could be a truce involving disputes over basic features and functions in Google's Android mobile software, one source said. But it's unclear whether Page and Cook are discussing a broad settlement of the various disputes between the two companies - most of which involve the burgeoning mobile computing area - or are focused on a more limited set of issues. Competition between Google and Apple has heated up in recent years with the shift from PCs to mobile devices. Google's Android software, which Apple's late founder Steve Jobs denounced as a "stolen product," has become the world's No.1 smartphone operating system even as it has embroiled the hardware vendors who use it, including Samsung and Google's Motorola unit, in patent infringement lawsuits. Apple in recent months has moved to lessen its reliance on Google's products. Apple recently unveiled its own mobile mapping software, replacing the Google product used in the iPhone, and said it would no longer offer Google's YouTube as a pre-loaded app in future versions of its iPhone. Cook took the helm at Apple a year ago, and Page stepped into the top job at Google just a few months before that. Apple and Google declined to comment on any discussions. (Reporting by Alexei Oreskovic and Poornima Gupta; Editing by Jonathan Weber, Martin Howell and Leslie Gevirtz) @yahoofinance on Twitter, become a fan on Facebook

Topic.Title: Tim Seymour called the top on Monday

Message.Msg: Maybe Monday was the top, maybe not. We have to go a lot lower to confirm a real top and end to the parabolic run. I wrote my thoughts about it around 5am ET (11am my time). For what it`s worth: What do AAPL`s mini pullbacks and up thrusts in parabolic mode look like? And what does a major correction at the end of parabolic mode look like? What to expect here after yesterday`s close of 674ish? These would be thrusts and pullbacks that could occur over the course of 1 to 3 trading days. This is predicated on AAPL remaining parabolic or semi-parabolic for at least 8 more trading days. At our current level of roughly 674, these would look like this, from the top down: Extreme thrust up 693 Sharp thrust up 682 Normal thrust up 678 Neutral ---------- Normal pullback 668 Sharp pullback 663 Extreme pullback 656 When AAPL corrects from a parabolic-run TOP, it is much more extreme. For example, if Monday at 680.87 was/had indeed been the top, we could expect to see 645 by Friday or Tuesday and 633 over the next 10 days and 622 over the next 2 weeks and 600-595 over the next 10-12 weeks, before another blast off. If Monday was just a swing high in a continuing parabolic or even semi-parabolic run we could easily see between 690 and 710 by September 12. Sideways over the next 2 wks. would be consolidation between 660 and 680. And that`s never bad. Personally I`m expecting a “local” top around 710 followed by a 35 to 65 point correction over 2 months (a wild guess really), before a run up to 830. That assumes i-5 will be a high-5. Okay, a wild guess.

Topic.Title: Frank Capra,, Funny, Chalk, are u's making money?

Message.Msg: I never stated I followed Frank's advice religiously. Nor did I state I have been trading for 20+ years. I have traded seriously for close to five years prior to that I played with the market for another two trying to learn as I went along. Frank is a bit zealous when it comes to his picks. I took some of his ideas, performed my own research, purchased/sold when I felt the time was right. Over the past five years my average return is 37.6% annually. Does that make me a hotshot...not by my assessment. It makes me rather lucky to have been able to recover from an up and down market while continuing to grow my portfolio. I made nice returns on aapl 2013 and 2014 leaps that I sold earlier this year. I sat in cash for a bit waited for appl to fall and bought 2014 leaps for a second time. I am up 30% with the second purchase of 2014 leaps. Outside aapl I have made decent gains on ddd and fio but I have yet to lock in those gains. Technology has been big for me over the past year before that I played quite a bit with energy.

Topic.Title: Extra Idiots in the Sandbox Today

Message.Msg: Like most, I am not good at near-term calls. So, the price going into 9/12 is difficult to say. I will say this. After earnings are announced in October, aapl's ttm eps will be around $45. I see the PE growing from 15.6 today to 16 by late October. So, my pps estimate for late October is $720. From there until late January, when FQ1 2013 earnings are announced, I see further growth in the PE to 17 on the back of preliminary news of new iPhone and iPad Mini sales...and possibly a China Mobile deal. So, my pps estimate for late January 2013 is $765 going into that earnings announcement. I then see a $20 FQ1 2013 being announced in late January. That would bring the ttm eps to $51. With the PE at 17, the pps after that earnings announcement will be $867 in February/March 2013. Hey, you asked. :)

Message.Msg: The analysts are mostly wrong about China for Apple. Here's why: 1. China's Apple growth are very limited because apple's products are too expensive and it'll be very hard for Apple to compete with local small phone companies. 2. Topic.Title: Extra Idiots in the Sandbox Today

Message.Msg: I'm so surprised that so many people are focusing on P/E ratio or PEG for apple..But I have a different opinion: that valuation method does not apply for public company of Apple's size. Doesn't matter it's high or low..Stock price is based on foreseeable future cash flow. Petrol China was once the biggest company of all time, one nearly one trillion market capital, but everyone who got it at that time has only 1/4 of their investment left now. The bigger the company is, the more difficult for it to grow, the more volitile the earning will be (for consumer electronics) and more risky in case something happens. Samsung made 42 billion revenue last quarter, but only 5 billion profit Apple make 35 billion in revenue but 8.8 billion profit last quarter---The key is the margin, how sustainable this high margin can be? For a matured divident company, especially the world's largest public company, apple's P/E should be around 10 or less. Maybe I'm saying this too early, but we'll see how it'll play out eventually.

Topic.Title: Extra Idiots in the Sandbox Today

Message.Msg: I realize it's unfashionable in this day and age to follow a BUY-and-HOLD approach to investing, but I still think (after 35 years of active investing) it's a time honored way to make the best returns on invested capital, especially when a company is doing something fundamentally great, like Apple is now. I'm late to the party myself. I purchased my first APPLE shares last October, less than a year ago, on the day the 4S was announced. Market hated it wasn't a "5", stock sold off some, and I jumped in at the "bargain" price of $367. Since then I've added some shares in the low 400's, high 400's and even high 500's simply because Apple's fundamentals are intact and strengthening. I don't have a "price target" per se. I'll get out when the story changes and Apple runs out of gas, but the "i" franchise has legs and should run hard through next year into 2014. Daily fluctuations mean absolutely nothing to me; I'm not trading it.
